content.title: Thyroid Storm
content.summary: Life-threatening decompensated hyperthyroidism characterized by severe thyrotoxicosis with fever, tachycardia, altered mental status, and multi-organ dysfunction requiring immediate ICU-level intervention
key_points: Medical emergency with mortality 10-30% even with treatment
Usually precipitated by infection, surgery, trauma, or iodine load in uncontrolled hyperthyroidism
Burch-Wartofsky score >45 diagnostic; 25-44 suggests impending storm
Treatment sequence: Beta-blocker → PTU → Iodine (1 hour after PTU) → Steroids → Supportive care
PTU preferred over methimazole (blocks T4→T3 conversion)
Iodine given AFTER antithyroid drugs to prevent iodine-induced hormone synthesis
Steroids block T4→T3 conversion and treat possible relative adrenal insufficiency
content.statement: Thyroid storm is a life-threatening endocrine emergency representing extreme decompensated thyrotoxicosis with fever, severe tachycardia, altered mental status, and multi-organ dysfunction requiring immediate aggressive multimodal treatment.

explanation.intuition: Thyroid storm is hyperthyroidism in crisis - the body's metabolic engine is revving so high it's about to fail. The extreme hypermetabolic state generates dangerously high body temperature and puts unsustainable demands on the heart.
explanation.key_insight: Treatment of thyroid storm requires blocking thyroid hormone effects at multiple levels simultaneously: beta-blockers for adrenergic symptoms, antithyroid drugs to stop new hormone synthesis, iodine to block hormone release, and steroids to inhibit peripheral conversion. Order matters - iodine must come after antithyroid drugs.
explanation.technical_details: The pathophysiology involves massive catecholamine-like effects from thyroid hormone excess. There is no threshold T4/T3 level that defines storm; it's a clinical diagnosis. The Burch-Wartofsky Point Scale (BWPS) uses temperature, CNS effects, GI/hepatic dysfunction, cardiovascular dysfunction, and heart failure to score severity.

definitions_glossary.thyrotoxicosis: Systemic effects of excessive thyroid hormone, regardless of source
definitions_glossary.burch_wartofsky_score: Clinical scoring system for thyroid storm diagnosis; >45 diagnostic, 25-44 impending
definitions_glossary.propylthiouracil: Antithyroid drug preferred in storm; blocks synthesis AND peripheral T4→T3 conversion
definitions_glossary.saturated_potassium_iodide: SSKI given 1 hour after PTU to block thyroid hormone release (Wolff-Chaikoff effect)
definitions_glossary.wolff_chaikoff_effect: Acute inhibition of thyroid hormone synthesis by high iodine concentrations
definitions_glossary.lugols_solution: Potassium iodide solution alternative to SSKI
definitions_glossary.propranolol: Non-selective beta-blocker preferred; also inhibits T4→T3 conversion
definitions_glossary.hydrocortisone: Glucocorticoid used in storm for relative adrenal insufficiency and T4→T3 inhibition
definitions_glossary.decompensated_hyperthyroidism: Loss of physiologic compensation in severe thyrotoxicosis
definitions_glossary.hyperpyrexia: Extreme fever (>40°C/104°F) often seen in thyroid storm
definitions_glossary.high_output_heart_failure: Cardiac decompensation from sustained increased cardiac output demands
definitions_glossary.thyroid_encephalopathy: Altered mental status from extreme thyrotoxicosis; agitation to coma

pathophysiology.mechanism: Extreme thyrotoxicosis causing hypermetabolic state with hyperthermia, cardiovascular decompensation, and multi-organ dysfunction

organ_system_effects.cardiovascular: Severe tachycardia, atrial fibrillation, high-output heart failure, shock

burch_wartofsky_scoring.cns_effects: Mild agitation (10 pts) to coma/seizures (30 pts)

cardiovascular.heart_failure: Mild edema (5 pts) to pulmonary edema (15 pts)

clinical_presentation: Altered mental status (agitation, delirium, psychosis, coma)
Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response
Jaundice (indicates severe hepatic involvement - poor prognosis)
diagnostic_criteria.laboratory_findings: T4/T3 elevated but NOT distinguishably higher than uncomplicated hyperthyroidism; diagnosis is CLINICAL

treatment_sequence.order: Beta-blocker → PTU → Iodine (1 hour after PTU) → Steroids → Supportive care
treatment_sequence.rationale: Iodine after PTU prevents Jod-Basedow phenomenon (iodine-induced hormone synthesis)

beta_blockade.propranolol: 60-80 mg PO q4-6h or 0.5-1 mg IV slowly; preferred for additional T4→T3 blocking
beta_blockade.esmolol: 500 mcg/kg IV bolus, then 50-200 mcg/kg/min infusion if hemodynamically unstable
beta_blockade.goal: HR <100 bpm; use with caution in heart failure

antithyroid_drugs.ptu_preferred: 500-1000 mg loading, then 250 mg PO/NG q4h
antithyroid_drugs.rationale: PTU blocks synthesis AND inhibits peripheral T4→T3 conversion
antithyroid_drugs.methimazole_alternative: 20-25 mg PO/NG q6h if PTU unavailable

iodine_therapy.timing: MUST wait 1 hour after PTU before giving iodine
iodine_therapy.mechanism: Blocks thyroid hormone release via Wolff-Chaikoff effect

glucocorticoids.hydrocortisone: 100 mg IV q8h or dexamethasone 2 mg IV q6h
glucocorticoids.benefits: Inhibits T4→T3 conversion, treats relative adrenal insufficiency, reduces thyroid hormone secretion

supportive_care: Cooling measures for hyperthermia (avoid aspirin - displaces T4 from proteins)
Cholestyramine may help lower T4 levels

skos.definition: A life-threatening endocrine emergency characterized by extreme decompensated thyrotoxicosis with fever, severe tachycardia, altered mental status, and multi-organ dysfunction

subcodes: E05.51 - Thyrotoxic crisis or storm with thyrotoxic heart disease

learning_objectives: Recognize clinical features of thyroid storm using Burch-Wartofsky criteria
Implement ordered multimodal treatment (beta-blocker → PTU → iodine → steroids)
Explain why iodine must be given AFTER antithyroid drugs
Identify precipitating factors and treat underlying cause
Differentiate thyroid storm from uncomplicated hyperthyroidism
clinical_pearls: Thyroid storm is a CLINICAL diagnosis - T4/T3 levels don't distinguish from uncomplicated hyperthyroidism
Always give PTU at least 1 hour BEFORE iodine to prevent Jod-Basedow phenomenon
PTU is preferred over methimazole because it also blocks T4→T3 conversion
Avoid aspirin for fever - displaces T4 from binding proteins, worsening thyrotoxicosis
Jaundice is an ominous sign indicating severe hepatic involvement
Burch-Wartofsky score >45 highly suggestive of thyroid storm
Propranolol is preferred beta-blocker (also blocks T4→T3); use esmolol if hypotensive
Cholestyramine can be added to lower T4 levels by interrupting enterohepatic circulation
